content:
I’m a 2025 Computer Science and Engineering graduate — though if you had asked me a few years back, I’d have told you engineering was the last thing I wanted to pursue. I had my eyes on humanities, design, maybe even fashion or product design, but life had its own plans. Somewhere along the way, despite resisting it at first, I stepped into tech. Looking back now, I think it was one of the best decisions I’ve made.

I’ve always believed in manifestation and in the idea that what you focus on eventually shapes your reality. For a long time, I told myself that engineering wasn’t for me, yet here I am, finding joy in building, solving, and experimenting. To me, there’s a kind of magic in turning zeros and ones into something tangible — something that people can see, use, and benefit from.

My journey began with a strong love for mathematics — the kind that kept me solving tough problems even outside the syllabus. At the same time, I’ve carried a creative streak with me for over a decade as a self-taught portrait artist. That blend of analytical precision and artistic expression is something I bring into the way I build products: functional, yet crafted with care.

Over the past few years, I’ve had the chance to work with multiple startups and open-source projects, taking on everything from backend systems and complex frontends to AI workflows and even early AR/VR prototypes. Each experience taught me how to adapt, take ownership, and build things from scratch that are not only technically sound but also user-focused. Somewhere along the way, I realized that my true passion lies in solving niche, user-centric problems and creating experiences that feel like they were made just for the people using them.

Looking ahead, I’m deeply interested in how AI, AR, and VR can evolve into a cognitive layer that enhances human potential rather than just automating tasks. In the next five to seven years, my goal is to launch my own product and build a personal brand that reflects this vision.

Outside of work, I’m a mountain person at heart who loves traveling and finding calm in high altitudes. I enjoy bike rides — sometimes solo, sometimes in groups — and I find cooking therapeutic. My specialty? Gajar ka halwa, made with my mom’s recipe.

At the core of it all, I try to stay humble, grounded, and curious. Whether it’s through code, art, or even food, I see creation as a way of connecting with people and leaving something meaningful behind.
